75677.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Sandhi of 2nd sg. present “asi” (you are) + quotative particle “iti”. In the context tasmā ṭhitohaṃ tuvaṃ aṭṭhito sīti, it functions as a closing quotative, i.e. “(saying) ‘you are not standing’,” matching the English “but you have not,” where the content before iti is quoted.
75677.example_1: that’s why I’ve stopped, but you have not.”

23430.meaning_1: holding the doctrine of patience; professing patience; advocate of forbearance
23430.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context disā hi me khantivādānaṃ, khantivādānaṃ is genitive plural 'of the patience-doctrinaires; of those professing patience'. The entry is the adjectival/bahubbīhi-type use meaning 'one who holds the doctrine of patience', which as a noun can denote a follower or proponent of khanti.
23430.example_1: May even my enemies <j>hear Dhamma at the right time,

40677.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 86 the reading paṭibhattesu dhammesu contrasts with saṃvibhattesu etc., meaning “among things that have been apportioned/shared out.” The form is the past participle of paṭibhajati “to apportion, distribute.”
40677.example_1:
svāgataṃ [sāgataṃ] nāpagataṃ [nāma sagataṃ],
nayidaṃ dummantitaṃ mama,
saṃvibhattesu [suvibhattesu,
savibhattesu,
paṭibhattesu] dhammesu,
yaṃ seṭṭhaṃ tadupāgamaṃ.

16649.meaning_1: split open; cut open; tore out
16649.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Form is 3rd sg aorist uppāṭesi of causative uppāṭeti. In MN 87 it reports the man “split himself open” (upphālesi [uppāṭesi, ophāresi]), i.e. cut himself open; hence meanings emphasize “split/cut open; tore out.”
16649.example_1: ahañca taṃ na icchāmīti. atha kho so puriso taṃ itthiṃ dvidhā chetvā attānaṃ upphālesi [uppāṭesi, ophāresi], ubho pecca bhavissāmāti. imināpi kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā piyajātikā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā piyappabhavikāti.

11318.meaning_1: rinses; washes; gives water for rinsing
11318.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
The contextual form ācāmehīti is 2nd sg impv: 'rinse!' or 'perform the rinsing!', addressed to Queen Mallikā. As a causative, it can also imply 'offer water for rinsing'.
11318.example_1: yāvañca so bhagavā paññāya ativijjha maññe [paṭivijjha paññāya] passati. ehi, mallike, ācamehīti [ācāmehīti] . atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṃ udānaṃ udānesi, namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa, namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa, namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassāti.

27346.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 88, bāhitikā vatthanāḷiyā [chattanāḷiyā] pakkhipitvā: a “Bāhitikā” cloth sent in a tube/case, glossed as either a cloth-tube (vatthanāḷi) or an umbrella-tube (chattanāḷi). Hence chattanāḷi is a case or tube for a chatta (umbrella).
27346.example_1: api ca, bhante, mayampetaṃ [mayameva taṃ, mayampanetaṃ] jānāma, netaṃ āyasmato ānandassa kappatīti. ayaṃ me, bhante, bāhitikā raññā māgadhena ajātasattunā vedehiputtena vatthanāḷiyā [chattanāḷiyā] pakkhipitvā pahitā soḷasasamā āyāmena, aṭṭhasamā vitthārena. taṃ, bhante, āyasmā ānando paṭiggaṇhātu anukampaṃ upādāyāti.

11913.meaning_1: till the last breath; to one’s dying breath; lifelong
11913.meaning_lit: up to the end (limit) of breath
11913.compound_construction: ā (up to) + pāṇa (breath, life) + koṭi (limit, end) + ka (forming adverbial)
11913.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 89, āpāṇakoṭikaṃ qualifies brahmacariyaṃ carante, meaning they practice the holy life “to their last breath,” i.e., for the whole of their lives until life’s end. Though built from a nominal compound with -ka, it functions adverbially.
11913.sutta_1: idha panāhaṃ, bhante, bhikkhū passāmi yāvajīvaṃ āpāṇakoṭikaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carante.
11913.example_1: But here I see the mendicants leading the spiritual life entirely full and pure as long as they live, to their last breath.

46357.meaning_1: with delighted faculties; joyful in appearance
46357.phonetic: ī > i (before consonant cluster resolution in sandhi)
46357.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 89 the king describes monks as pīṇitindriyā “with delighted faculties,” i.e. visibly joyful and radiant. Form is bahubbīhi-like adjective qualifying persons; built from pp pīṇita “pleased, satisfied” + indriya “faculties.”
46357.example_1: te evamāhaṃsu, bandhukarogo no [paṇḍukarogino], mahārājāti. idha panāhaṃ, bhante, bhikkhū passāmi haṭṭhapahaṭṭhe udaggudagge abhiratarūpe pīṇindriye [pīṇitindriye] appossukke pannalome paradattavutte migabhūtena cetasā viharante. tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, etadahosi, addhā ime āyasmanto tassa bhagavato sāsane uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ jānanti, tathā hi ime āyasmanto haṭṭhapahaṭṭhā udaggudaggā abhiratarūpā pīṇindriyā appossukkā pannalomā paradattavuttā migabhūtena cetasā viharantīti.

14947.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Udaññā is a feminine place-name in the MN 90 Kaṇṇakatthala context: Bhagavā viharati … Udaññāyaṃ “dwelling at Udaññā.” The bracketed variants (Uruññā, Ujuññā, Udaññā) reflect manuscript traditions; this entry treats udaññā as the toponym in the lemma.
14947.example_1: 375. evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruññāyaṃ [ujuññāyaṃ, udaññāyaṃ] viharati kaṇṇakatthale migadāye. tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo uruññaṃ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.

62364.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 90 it occurs in the plural as part of a list: abhivādanapaccuṭṭhāna añjalikamma sāmīcikammāni, i.e. greetings, rising in respect, salutation with joined hands, and acts of proper conduct. Thus sāmicikamma denotes actions conforming to etiquette or due propriety.
62364.example_1: cattārome, mahārāja, vaṇṇā, khattiyā, brāhmaṇā, vessā, suddā. imesaṃ kho, mahārāja, catunnaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ dve vaṇṇā aggamakkhāyanti, khattiyā ca brāhmaṇā ca, yadidaṃ abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānaañjalikammasāmīcikammānīti [sāmicikammānanti] . nāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ diṭṭhadhammikaṃ pucchāmi, samparāyikāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ pucchāmi.

37472.meaning_1: issues forth; comes out; emerges; is produced
37472.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 90 the phrase viriyaṃ nippharati means “energy is produced/comes forth,” i.e. it emerges as a result of exertion (nimmathitaṃ padhānābhinibbattaṃ). The verb here is intransitive, denoting the arising or issuing forth of energy.
37472.example_1: no hetaṃ, bhante. evameva kho, mahārāja, yaṃ taṃ tejaṃ vīriyā nimmathitaṃ padhānābhinibbattaṃ [viriyaṃ nippharati, taṃ pacchābhinibbattaṃ], nāhaṃ tattha kiñci nānākaraṇaṃ vadāmi, yadidaṃ vimuttiyā vimuttinti. heturūpaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āha, saheturūpaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āha.

39625.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 90 the phrase taṃ pacchābhinibbattaṃ contrasts energy produced by striving with what is “later-produced.” Here it qualifies the resultant (viriya) that arises subsequently, hence “later generated.”
39625.example_1: no hetaṃ, bhante. evameva kho, mahārāja, yaṃ taṃ tejaṃ vīriyā nimmathitaṃ padhānābhinibbattaṃ [viriyaṃ nippharati, taṃ pacchābhinibbattaṃ], nāhaṃ tattha kiñci nānākaraṇaṃ vadāmi, yadidaṃ vimuttiyā vimuttinti. heturūpaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āha, saheturūpaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āha.

26511.meaning_1: to make move (from); to expel (from); to dislodge (from)
26511.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 90 the king’s power “tamhā ṭhānā cāvetuṃ vā” means the ability to remove or expel someone from a place. Hence the contextual sense is “to expel; to dislodge (from a place)”.
26511.sutta_1: yāvatā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa vijitaṃ yattha ca rājā pasenadi kosalo issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreti, pahoti tattha rājā pasenadi kosalo samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā puññavantaṃ vā apuññavantaṃ vā brahmacariyavantaṃ vā abrahmacariyavantaṃ vā tamhā ṭhānā cāvetuṃ vā pabbājetuṃ vā”ti?
26511.example_1: As far as the dominion of King Pasenadi of Kosala extends, where he rules as sovereign lord, can he topple or expel from that place any ascetic or brahmin, regardless of whether they are good or bad, or whether or not they are genuine spiritual practitioners?”

49076.meaning_1: Chapter 10 of the Majjhima Nikāya (MN91–100); the Brahmin chapter
49076.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the sentence “brāhmaṇavaggo niṭṭhito pañcamo.” it means “the Brāhmaṇa chapter is finished, the fifth.” In MN it designates the fifth vagga; the gloss “Chapter 10 (MN91–100)” is a conventional numbering by tens across vaggas, but here pañcamo confirms its position as the fifth chapter.

36563.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 91 the plural ubhopi nāsikasotāni refers to “both nostrils.” The compound is a kammadhāraya: sota “stream, channel” qualified by nāsikā “nose,” hence “nasal channel; nostril.”
36563.example_1: atha kho bhagavā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi yathā addasa uttaro māṇavo bhagavato kosohitaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ. atha kho bhagavā jivhaṃ ninnāmetvā ubhopi kaṇṇasotāni anumasi paṭimasi [parimasi], ubhopi nāsikasotāni [nāsikāsotāni] anumasi paṭimasi, kevalampi nalāṭamaṇḍalaṃ jivhāya chādesi. atha kho uttarassa māṇavassa etadahosi, samannāgato kho samaṇo gotamo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi.

16370.meaning_1: having grasped; having taken hold (of); having supported (with the hand)
16370.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 91 the phrase na ca pāṇinā hanukaṃ upadahitvā [upādiyitvā] nisīdati means “he does not sit having propped up (supported) his jaw with his hand.” Here upādiyitvā functions as an absolutive “having taken hold/supporting,” governing the accusative hanukaṃ.
16370.example_1: so nātidūre nāccāsanne āsanassa parivattati, na ca pāṇinā ālambitvā āsane nisīdati, na ca āsanasmiṃ kāyaṃ pakkhipati. so antaraghare nisinno samāno na hatthakukkuccaṃ āpajjati, na pādakukkuccaṃ āpajjati, na adduvena adduvaṃ āropetvā nisīdati, na ca gopphakena gopphakaṃ āropetvā nisīdati, na ca pāṇinā hanukaṃ upadahitvā [upādiyitvā] nisīdati. so antaraghare nisinno samāno na chambhati na kampati na vedhati na paritassati.

48617.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 91 the reading contrasts with khulukhulukārakaṃ. Here bulubulukārakaṃ pattaṃ dhovati means “he washes the bowl without making a bulubulu/gurgling sound,” i.e. without noisy splashing. The first member bulubulu is onomatopoeic for bubbling/gurgling; kāraka “maker, producing.” As a neuter compound noun it denotes the sound-producing act/thing.
48617.example_1: so pattodakaṃ paṭiggaṇhāti nātithokaṃ nātibahuṃ. so na khulukhulukārakaṃ [bulubulukārakaṃ] pattaṃ dhovati, na samparivattakaṃ pattaṃ dhovati, na pattaṃ bhūmiyaṃ nikkhipitvā hatthe dhovati, hatthesu dhotesu patto dhoto hoti, patte dhote hatthā dhotā honti. so pattodakaṃ chaḍḍeti nātidūre nāccāsanne, na ca vicchaḍḍayamāno.

10505.meaning_1: not abandoning; not giving up; not leaving behind
10505.meaning_2: not departing; not going away; remaining
10505.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 91, avalokayamānāyeva … avijahitattā/avijahantābhāvena indicates the audience leave while still looking back because they have not abandoned (i.e. have not left) the Teacher; hence “not departing; remaining attached.”
10505.example_1: yathāparisaṃ kho pana so bhavaṃ gotamo sarena viññāpeti, na cassa bahiddhā parisāya ghoso niccharati. te tena bhotā gotamena dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamanti avalokayamānāyeva [apalokayamānāyeva] avijahitattā [avijahantābhāvena] . addasāma kho mayaṃ, bho, taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ gacchantaṃ, addasāma ṭhitaṃ, addasāma antaragharaṃ pavisantaṃ, addasāma antaraghare nisinnaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ, addasāma antaraghare bhuñjantaṃ, addasāma bhuttāviṃ nisinnaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ, addasāma bhuttāviṃ anumodantaṃ, addasāma ārāmaṃ gacchantaṃ, addasāma ārāmagataṃ nisinnaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ, addasāma ārāmagataṃ parisati dhammaṃ desentaṃ.

21259.meaning_1: physical assistance; bodily service; manual help
21259.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 92, Keṇiya asks his relatives to do kāyaveyyāvatikaṃ, i.e. practical bodily tasks to prepare the meal: digging hearths, splitting wood, washing vessels, setting water and seats. Formed from kāya + veyyāvacca with taddhita -ika, meaning “things of service relating to the body,” hence “physical service/help.”
21259.example_1: atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena sako assamo tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā mittāmacce ñātisālohite āmantesi, suṇantu me bhonto, mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā, samaṇo me gotamo nimantito svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena. yena me kāyaveyyāvaṭikaṃ [kāyaveyāvaṭṭikaṃ, kāyaveyyāvatikaṃ] kareyyāthāti. evaṃ, bhoti kho keṇiyassa jaṭilassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā keṇiyassa jaṭilassa paṭissutvā appekacce uddhanāni khaṇanti, appekacce kaṭṭhāni phālenti, appekacce bhājanāni dhovanti, appekacce udakamaṇikaṃ patiṭṭhāpenti, appekacce āsanāni paññapenti.

65953.meaning_1: colourful; bright in appearance; of fine complexion
65953.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 93 the reading vaṇṇimā contrasts fires as “bright-coloured, radiant.” Form is the -mant adjective from vaṇṇī “coloured, comely,” used predicatively (nom sg masc vaṇṇimā).
65953.example_1: taṃ kiṃ maññasi, assalāyana, yo evaṃ nu kho so [yo ca nu kho] khattiyakulā brāhmaṇakulā rājaññakulā uppannehi sākassa vā sālassa vā salaḷassa vā candanassa vā padumakassa vā uttarāraṇiṃ ādāya aggi abhinibbatto, tejo pātukato, so eva nu khvāssa aggi accimā ceva [ca] vaṇṇavā [vaṇṇimā] ca pabhassaro ca, tena ca sakkā agginā aggikaraṇīyaṃ kātuṃ, yo pana so caṇḍālakulā nesādakulā venakulā rathakārakulā pukkusakulā uppannehi sāpānadoṇiyā vā sūkaradoṇiyā vā rajakadoṇiyā vā eraṇḍakaṭṭhassa vā uttarāraṇiṃ ādāya aggi abhinibbatto, tejo pātukato svāssa aggi na ceva accimā na ca vaṇṇavā na ca pabhassaro, na ca tena sakkā agginā aggikaraṇīyaṃ kātunti? no hidaṃ, bho gotama!

70156.sanskrit: vaikṛta-ja? (uncertain); cf. Skt aśvatara “mule” for sense
70156.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 93, the reading is uncertain in manuscripts; the sense demands “mule-born.” The context contrasts a mare paired with a donkey producing a mule (assataro). “Vekulaja” explains the offspring as of mule-kind, i.e., a hybrid. Formed with -ja “born of.”
70156.example_1: taṃ kiṃ maññasi, assalāyana idha vaḷavaṃ gadrabhena sampayojeyyuṃ [saṃyojeyya], tesaṃ sampayogamanvāya kisoro jāyetha, yo so vaḷavāya gadrabhena kisoro uppanno, siyā so mātupi sadiso pitupi sadiso, assotipi vattabbo gadrabhotipi vattabboti? kuṇḍañhi so [vekurañjāya hi so, so kumāraṇḍupi so, vekulajo hi so (?)], bho gotama, assataro hoti. idaṃ hissa, bho gotama, nānākaraṇaṃ passāmi, amutra ca panesānaṃ na kiñci nānākaraṇaṃ passāmīti.

1679.meaning_1: a kind of shoe; wooden clog; sandal with raised sole
1679.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 93 the reading paṭaliyo [aṭaliyo, agaliyo] upāhanā shows variant spellings; aṭaliyo is fem pl nom of aṭali, glossed as a kind of footwear akin to wooden clogs, paired with upāhanā “shoes/sandals.” The form in the headword is the lemma; context describes Devala putting on such footwear before going to the brahmins.
1679.example_1: assosi kho, assalāyana, asito devalo isi, sattannaṃ kira brāhmaṇisīnaṃ araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭīsu sammantānaṃ evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ, brāhmaṇova seṭṭho vaṇṇo … brahmadāyādāti. atha kho, assalāyana, asito devalo isi kesamassuṃ kappetvā mañjiṭṭhavaṇṇāni dussāni nivāsetvā paṭaliyo [aṭaliyo, agaliyo] upāhanā āruhitvā jātarūpamayaṃ daṇḍaṃ gahetvā sattannaṃ brāhmaṇisīnaṃ patthaṇḍile pāturahosi. atha kho, assalāyana, asito devalo isi sattannaṃ brāhmaṇisīnaṃ patthaṇḍile caṅkamamāno evamāha, handa, ko nu kho ime bhavanto brāhmaṇisayo gatā [gantā], handa, ko nu kho ime bhavanto brāhmaṇisayo gatāti?

517.sanskrit: agṛhī (cf. agṛhīta “unseized”, but cf. Pkt agali “unbarred”)
517.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 93 variant readings list paṭaliyo [aṭaliyo, agaliyo] upāhanā; agali appears as an adverb/adjectival indeclinable meaning “unbarred, open” (of sandals: straps loose/unfastened). Formed with privative a- + gali “latch, fastening.”
517.example_1: assosi kho, assalāyana, asito devalo isi, sattannaṃ kira brāhmaṇisīnaṃ araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭīsu sammantānaṃ evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ, brāhmaṇova seṭṭho vaṇṇo … brahmadāyādāti. atha kho, assalāyana, asito devalo isi kesamassuṃ kappetvā mañjiṭṭhavaṇṇāni dussāni nivāsetvā paṭaliyo [aṭaliyo, agaliyo] upāhanā āruhitvā jātarūpamayaṃ daṇḍaṃ gahetvā sattannaṃ brāhmaṇisīnaṃ patthaṇḍile pāturahosi. atha kho, assalāyana, asito devalo isi sattannaṃ brāhmaṇisīnaṃ patthaṇḍile caṅkamamāno evamāha, handa, ko nu kho ime bhavanto brāhmaṇisayo gatā [gantā], handa, ko nu kho ime bhavanto brāhmaṇisayo gatāti?

26215.meaning_1: fickle; giddy; flighty; impudent (as a term of abuse)
26215.meaning_2: you flighty one; you impudent one
26215.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 93 the word occurs in the abusive vocative list bhasmā, vasala, capalī; here capalī functions as a pejorative address meaning “you flighty/impudent one,” derived from capala.
26215.example_1: handa, naṃ abhisapāmāti. atha kho, assalāyana, satta brāhmaṇisayo asitaṃ devalaṃ isiṃ abhisapiṃsu, bhasmā, vasala [vasalī, vasali, capalī], hohi, bhasmā, vasala, hohīti [bhasmā vasala hohīti abhisapavacanaṃ sī. pī.

25078.meaning_1: (gram) term of praise; honorific epithet; laudatory expression
25078.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 95 the plural guṇapadānaṃ ‘of terms of praise’ refers to laudatory epithets applied to the Buddha by kings and brahmins (e.g. ‘gone for refuge with family’), hence a set of praising expressions rather than a physical ‘portion’. The compound is kammadhāraya: guṇa ‘good quality, virtue’ + pada ‘word, term’.
25078.example_1: ni. 1.304 aññānipi guṇapadānaṃ dissanti] samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro saputtadāro pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato … samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ rājā pasenadi kosalo saputtadāro pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato … samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti saputtadāro pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato … samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo opāsādaṃ anuppatto opāsāde viharati uttarena opāsādaṃ devavane sālavane. ye kho te samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā amhākaṃ gāmakkhettaṃ āgacchanti, atithī no te honti.

20949.meaning_lit: one of cloth; rag-man; (fig.) sham, pretender
20949.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
The reading kāpaṭiko [var. kāpaṭhiko, kāpadiko] in MN 95 is a personal epithet of the young Brahmin student. The form kāpadika in the prompt reflects a variant/orthographic error; standard Pāli has kāpaṭika “hypocrite, impostor,” often derived from kappaṭa “cloth, rag; sham.” Here it functions as a personal nickname meaning “the pretender/impostor.”
20949.example_1: tena kho pana samayena bhagavā vuddhehi vuddhehi brāhmaṇehi saddhiṃ kiñci kiñci kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā nisinno hoti. tena kho pana samayena kāpaṭiko [kāpaṭhiko, kāpadiko] nāma māṇavo daharo vuttasiro soḷasavassuddesiko jātiyā, tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ, padako, veyyākaraṇo, lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti. so vuddhānaṃ vuddhānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ bhagavatā saddhiṃ mantayamānānaṃ antarantarā kathaṃ opāteti.

32200.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 96 the phrase puriso daḷiddo assako anāḷhiyo describes “a poor man, without property, not wealthy.” Here daḷiddo is nominative singular functioning predicatively.
32200.example_1: no hidaṃ, bho gotama. seyyathāpi, brāhmaṇa, puriso daliddo [daḷiddo] assako anāḷhiyo. tassa akāmassa bilaṃ olaggeyyuṃ, idaṃ te, ambho purisa, maṃsaṃ khāditabbaṃ, mūlañca anuppadātabbanti.

66363.meaning_1: tie with a strap; leather fastening; thong binding
66363.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 97 the variant varattabandhanena occurs in a simile: “a strong man would put a head-band wrapping on the head with a strong thong-bond,” illustrating intense head pain. Here varatta means a strap/thong and bandhana a fastening; the compound denotes binding with a thong.
66363.example_1: abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo. seyyathāpi, bho sāriputta, balavā puriso daḷhena varattakkhaṇḍena [varattabandhanena] sīse sīsaveṭhaṃ dadeyya, evameva kho, bho sāriputta, adhimattā sīse sīsavedanā. na me, bho sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ.

28170.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Proper name of a wealthy and well-known Brahmin resident at Icchānaṅgala, listed among brahmin magnates in MN 98. Forms vary in the manuscripts: jāṇussoṇi/jāṇusoṇī/jāṇusoṇi; nominative sg is jāṇusoṇī. The Sanskrit identification is uncertain; sometimes compared with Jānaśruti.
28170.example_1: evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā icchānaṅgale [icchānaṅkale] viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe. tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇamahāsālā icchānaṅgale paṭivasanti, seyyathidaṃ, caṅkī brāhmaṇo, tārukkho brāhmaṇo, pokkharasāti brāhmaṇo, jāṇussoṇi [jāṇussoṇī, jāṇusoṇī] brāhmaṇo, todeyyo brāhmaṇo, aññe ca abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇamahāsālā. atha kho vāseṭṭhabhāradvājānaṃ māṇavānaṃ jaṅghāvihāraṃ anucaṅkamantānaṃ anuvicarantānaṃ [anucaṅkamamānānaṃ anuvicaramānānaṃ] ayamantarākathā udapādi, kathaṃ, bho, brāhmaṇo hotīti?

78365.meaning_1: (of a fire) kindles; lights; sets on fire
78365.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “aggiṃ jāleyya,” it is a volitive/optative of the causative jāleti meaning “would kindle a fire; would set a fire alight,” with the object in the accusative (aggiṃ).
78365.sutta_1: yaṃ vā tiṇakaṭṭhupādānaṃ paṭicca aggiṃ jāleyya yaṃ vā nissaṭṭhatiṇakaṭṭhupādānaṃ aggiṃ jāleyya, katamo nu khvāssa aggi accimā ceva vaṇṇavā ca pabhassaro cā”ti?
78365.example_1: Which would have better flames, color, and radiance: a fire that depends on grass and logs as fuel, or one that does not?”

45339.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the MN99 contextual note “pāṭhoyeva” refers to the textual reading itself, i.e. ‘just the text/reading’, not to a variant reading (which is pāṭha 1). Meaning here: the passage as it stands fits the simile perfectly.
45339.example_1: evaṃ bhāvitāya kho, māṇava, mettāya cetovimuttiyā yaṃ pamāṇakataṃ kammaṃ na taṃ tatrāvasissati, na taṃ tatrāvatiṭṭhati. seyyathāpi, māṇava, balavā saṅkhadhamo appakasireneva cātuddisā viññāpeyya [evameva kho māṇava evaṃ bhāvitāya mettāya (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī. dī. ni. 1.556) tathāpi idha pāṭhoyeva upamāya saṃsandiyamāno paripuṇṇo viya dissati], evameva kho, māṇava … evaṃ bhāvitāya kho, māṇava, mettāya [evameva kho māṇava evaṃ bhāvitāya mettāya (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī. dī. ni. 1.556) tathāpi idha pāṭhoyeva upamāya saṃsandiyamāno paripuṇṇo viya dissati] cetovimuttiyā yaṃ pamāṇakataṃ kammaṃ na taṃ tatrāvasissati, na taṃ tatrāvatiṭṭhati. ayampi kho, māṇava, brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggo.

50895.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 100 Saṅgāravasutta, the reading maṇḍalakappe locative sg indicates “in the circular district,” i.e. a local administrative area. Alternate readings list cañcalikappe, paccalakappe, caṇḍalakappe, but maṇḍalakappe is supported as a toponym-like compound meaning a region (kappa) defined as circular (maṇḍala).
50895.example_1: evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ carati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ. tena kho pana samayena dhanañjānī [dhānañjānī] nāma brāhmaṇī cañcalikappe [maṇḍalakappe, paccalakappe, caṇḍalakappe] paṭivasati abhippasannā buddhe ca dhamme ca saṅghe ca. atha kho dhanañjānī brāhmaṇī upakkhalitvā tikkhattuṃ udānaṃ udānesi, namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa.

39408.meaning_1: name of a district; region; locality
39408.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Occurs in MN 100 as an alternative reading to maṇḍalakappa and cañcalikappa/caṇḍalakappa, referring to the place where the brāhmaṇī Dhanañjānī resided. Treated as a masculine toponym in -a with nom. sg. -o.
39408.example_1: evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ carati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ. tena kho pana samayena dhanañjānī [dhānañjānī] nāma brāhmaṇī cañcalikappe [maṇḍalakappe, paccalakappe, caṇḍalakappe] paṭivasati abhippasannā buddhe ca dhamme ca saṅghe ca. atha kho dhanañjānī brāhmaṇī upakkhalitvā tikkhattuṃ udānaṃ udānesi, namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa.

43109.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 100, referring to dhanañjānī brāhmaṇī: parābhūtā means “ruined; disgraced,” implying she has suffered downfall (parābhava) and loss of status; contrasts with the variant parabhūtā (with contraction of ā).
43109.example_1: assosi kho saṅgāravo māṇavo dhanañjāniyā brāhmaṇiyā evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsamānāya. sutvā dhanañjāniṃ brāhmaṇiṃ etadavoca, avabhūtāva ayaṃ [avabhūtā cayaṃ] dhanañjānī brāhmaṇī, parabhūtāva ayaṃ [parābhūtā cayaṃ] dhanañjānī brāhmaṇī, vijjamānānaṃ (tevijjānaṃ) [( ) sī. syā.

50753.meaning_1: Section 2 of the Majjhima Nikāya; Middle Fifty Suttas
50753.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the sentence “majjhimapaṇṇāsakaṃ samattaṃ.” it is neuter nominative/accusative singular as a book title, meaning “the Middle Fifty is complete.”

57931.grammar: ind, adv, comp, instr sg of satthuvasa
57931.meaning_1: by the Teacher; according to the Teacher; in terms of the Teacher
57931.meaning_lit: by the influence of the Teacher
57931.construction:
satthu + vasa + ena
satthar + vasa + ena
57931.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Instr sg adverb of satthuvasa ‘influence/authority of the Teacher’. In the context sekkhavasena [satthāravasena, satthuvasena] it means ‘by the Teacher’s standpoint/method’, i.e. classified according to the Teacher.

45074.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 2 Sabbāsavasutta: dassanā pahātabbāsavā = “the effluents to be abandoned by seeing.” The compound is a kammadhāraya: pahātabba qualifies āsava; instrumental expresses the means (e.g. dassanā).

29159.meaning_1: gadflies, mosquitoes, wind, heat and creepy crawlies
29159.compound_construction: ḍaṃsā ca makasā ca vāto ca ātapo ca sarīṃsapā ca
29159.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 2 the compound occurs within the phrase “ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīṃsapa-samphassānaṃ paṭighātāya,” meaning “for the protection against the contact of gadflies, mosquitoes, wind, heat, and creepy-crawlies.” The form here is the dvanda compound enumerating harms warded off by the robe; neuter stem in -a.
29159.example_1: katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā? idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso cīvaraṃ paṭisevati, yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāya, uṇhassa paṭighātāya, ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīṃsapa- [siriṃsapa] samphassānaṃ paṭighātāya, yāvadeva hirikopīnappaṭicchādanatthaṃ.

59595.meaning_2: one who causes others to undertake; promoter
59595.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 4, bhavaṃ tesaṃ gotamo samādāpetā describes the Buddha as “the one who encourages (them),” i.e. the leader who incites or prompts the faithful to undertake the holy life.
59595.example_1: sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ [sārāṇīyaṃ] vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca, yeme, bho gotama, kulaputtā bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ uddissa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, bhavaṃ tesaṃ gotamo pubbaṅgamo, bhavaṃ tesaṃ gotamo bahukāro, bhavaṃ tesaṃ gotamo samādapetā [samādāpetā (?)], bhoto ca pana gotamassa sā janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjatīti. evametaṃ, brāhmaṇa, evametaṃ, brāhmaṇa!

78012.meaning_1: realm of desire; sphere of want
78012.meaning_2: range of desire; domain of wanting; sphere where desire operates
78012.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 5 “pāpakā akusalā icchāvacarā” refers to bad, unskillful spheres of desire not abandoned by a bhikkhu. Here icchāvacara functions substantivally as “(fields/spheres) of desire,” plural in context.
78012.sutta_1: yassa kassaci, āvuso, bhikkhuno ime pāpakā akusalā icchāvacarā appahīnā dissanti ceva sūyanti ca, kiñcāpi so hoti āraññiko pantasenāsano piṇḍapātiko sapadānacārī paṃsukūliko lūkhacīvaradharo, atha kho naṃ sabrahmacārī na ceva sakkaronti na garuṃ karonti na mānenti na pūjenti.
78012.example_1: Suppose these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by a mendicant. Even though they dwell in the wilderness, in remote lodgings, eat only almsfood, wander indiscriminately for almsfood, wear rag robes, and wear shabby robes, their spiritual companions don’t honor, respect, revere, and venerate them.

40230.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 5 the form (with variants pāṭikulyatā/paṭikkūlyatā) occurs in a list of negative qualities; here it means a sense of aversion or loathing arising on seeing something disagreeable.
40230.example_1: tamenaṃ uṭṭhahitvā apāpuritvā [avāpuritvā] olokeyya. tassa sahadassanena amanāpatā ca saṇṭhaheyya, pāṭikulyatā [paṭikūlatā, pāṭikūlyatā] ca saṇṭhaheyya, jegucchatā ca [jegucchitā ca] saṇṭhaheyya, jighacchitānampi na bhottukamyatā assa, pageva suhitānaṃ. evameva kho, āvuso, yassa kassaci bhikkhuno ime pāpakā akusalā icchāvacarā appahīnā dissanti ceva sūyanti ca, kiñcāpi so hoti āraññiko pantasenāsano piṇḍapātiko sapadānacārī paṃsukūliko lūkhacīvaradharo, atha kho naṃ sabrahmacārī na ceva sakkaronti na garuṃ karonti na mānenti na pūjenti.

45313.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Abstract feminine from pāṭikūla “repulsive/contrary.” In MN 5 it is coordinated with amanāpatā and jegucchatā, describing the arising of a feeling of repulsion or disagreeableness upon seeing an unclean object; thus here: “a sense of repulsiveness.” Related Skt prātikūlya/prātikūlyatā confirms formation. The -ya- + -tā yields stem pāṭikūlyat-.
45313.example_1: tamenaṃ uṭṭhahitvā apāpuritvā [avāpuritvā] olokeyya. tassa sahadassanena amanāpatā ca saṇṭhaheyya, pāṭikulyatā [paṭikūlatā, pāṭikūlyatā] ca saṇṭhaheyya, jegucchatā ca [jegucchitā ca] saṇṭhaheyya, jighacchitānampi na bhottukamyatā assa, pageva suhitānaṃ. evameva kho, āvuso, yassa kassaci bhikkhuno ime pāpakā akusalā icchāvacarā appahīnā dissanti ceva sūyanti ca, kiñcāpi so hoti āraññiko pantasenāsano piṇḍapātiko sapadānacārī paṃsukūliko lūkhacīvaradharo, atha kho naṃ sabrahmacārī na ceva sakkaronti na garuṃ karonti na mānenti na pūjenti.

10999.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
ākaṅkheyya is the optative of ākaṅkhati “to wish, desire.” In context mn6:0.2, ākaṅkheyyasutta is the title “One Might Wish.”

24551.meaning_1: respected; honoured; held in high esteem; worthy of respect
24551.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 6 Ākaṅkheyyasutta, the phrase piyo ca assaṃ manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cāti [manāpo garubhāvaniyo cāti] shows the compressed reading manāpo garubhāvaniyo: “agreeable and worthy of respect.” The compound means “worthy to be regarded with weight/respect,” aligning with bhāvanīya ‘to be cultivated/esteemed.’
24551.example_1: 65. ākaṅkheyya ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu, sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca assaṃ manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cāti [manāpo garubhāvaniyo cāti], sīlesvevassa paripūrakārī ajjhattaṃ cetosamathamanuyutto anirākatajjhāno vipassanāya samannāgato brūhetā suññāgārānaṃ.

26853.compound_construction: cīvara ca piṇḍapāta ca senāsana ca
26853.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 6, the compound occurs in the list of the four requisites: robes (cīvara), alms-food (piṇḍapāta), lodgings (senāsana), and medicine (gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāra). Here it is governed by yesāhaṃ … paribhuñjāmi “the things by which I make use”.
26853.example_1: ākaṅkheyya ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu, yesāhaṃ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsana gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ paribhuñjāmi tesaṃ te kārā mahapphalā assu mahānisaṃsāti, sīlesvevassa paripūrakārī ajjhattaṃ cetosamathamanuyutto anirākatajjhāno vipassanāya samannāgato brūhetā suññāgārānaṃ.

66069.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In context mn7:0.2, vatthasutta is the title of MN7, translated as “The Simile of the Cloth.” It is a kammadhāraya compound meaning “cloth discourse.”

53303.meaning_1: considered liberating; deemed to purify; regarded as giving release
53303.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 7, said of the river Bāhukā as mokkhasammatā (variant of lokkha/lokhya readings), i.e. “considered liberating/purifying” by many people, in parallel with puññasammatā.
53303.example_1: kiṃ bāhukā nadī karissatīti? lokkhasammatā [lokhyasammatā, mokkhasammatā] hi, bho gotama, bāhukā nadī bahujanassa, puññasammatā hi, bho gotama, bāhukā nadī bahujanassa, bāhukāya pana nadiyā bahujano pāpakammaṃ kataṃ pavāhetīti. atha kho bhagavā sundarikabhāradvājaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi –

39112.meaning_2: one who rushes in; impetuous person
39112.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In niccampi bālo pakkhando “a fool can constantly plunge into them,” pakkhando functions as a predicate noun/adjective meaning one who plunges in, i.e. an impetuous transgressor who rushes into the defilements or dangers.
39112.example_1: a fool can constantly plunge into them

8442.meaning_1: unselfish; generous; not stingy; free from avarice
8442.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In mn15:6.40, amaccharī qualifies the intended mental state to be developed, meaning 'free from stinginess' or 'generous' in contrast to macchariya/macchera. The entry '2' is redundant; there is no distinct secondary sense separate from the general adjectival use.
8442.sutta_1: evaṃ jānantenāvuso, bhikkhunā ‘anissukī bhavissāmi amaccharī’ti cittaṃ uppādetabbaṃ.

61224.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “sallekhasutta — Self-Effacement”, the headword is the title of MN8, commonly translated as “The Discourse on Effacement,” hence meaning_2 includes “Self-Effacement.” The compound is a kammadhāraya: sallekha (effacement, self-scrutiny that erases defilements) + sutta (discourse).

25895.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “catuttālīsapadā vuttā,” the word is plural instrumental, meaning “forty-four items (terms) have been stated.” The headword is a digu compound of the numeral catuttālīsa and pada.

62087.meaning_1: like the ocean; comparable to the sea
62087.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In mn8:17.9 gambhīro sāgarūpamoti, sāgarūpama qualifies gambhīro “deep,” meaning “deep like the ocean.” The ū arises from contraction of upa + ama (upama) after a, giving ū in compounds of -ūpama.
62087.example_1: which is deep as the ocean.

60809.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “sammādiṭṭhisutta — Right View”, the headword is the discourse title (MN 9), literally “Right-view discourse”: sammā (right, proper) + diṭṭhi (view) + sutta (discourse).

25865.meaning_1: four-fold method; method in terms of fours
25865.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 9 verse material the phrase “avijjāya catukkanayo” means “a fourfold method with respect to ignorance”, listing four items under avijjā. The compound is a kammadhāraya: catukka qualifying naya.
25865.example_1: [ito paraṃ kesuci potthakesu imāpi gāthāyo§evaṃ dissanti –§dukkhaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ upādānaṃ, saḷāyatanaṃ nāmarūpaṃ. viññāṇaṃ yā sā pare, katamā panāvuso padānaṃ§kiṃ jāti taṇhā ca vedanā, avijjāya catukkanayo. cattāri pare katamā, panāvuso padānaṃ kevalaṃ§āhāro ca bhavo phasso, saṅkhāro āsavapañcamo.

12838.meaning_1: with the effluents as the fifth; having āsava as the fifth
12838.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 9 list “āhāro ca bhavo phasso, saṅkhāro āsavapañcamo,” it marks āsava as the fifth item in the series of nutriment, becoming, contact, formations, with effluents as the fifth.
12838.example_1: viññāṇaṃ yā sā pare, katamā panāvuso padānaṃ§kiṃ jāti taṇhā ca vedanā, avijjāya catukkanayo. cattāri pare katamā, panāvuso padānaṃ kevalaṃ§āhāro ca bhavo phasso, saṅkhāro āsavapañcamo. yāva pañca pare katamā, panāvuso padānaṃ kiṃ§katamanti chabbidhā vuttaṃ, katamāni catubbidhāni.

27498.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Digu bahubbīhi-like numeral + vidha compound meaning 'of six kinds'. In the MN9 context, chabbidha qualifies a set enumerated as sixfold.
27498.example_1: cattāri pare katamā, panāvuso padānaṃ kevalaṃ§āhāro ca bhavo phasso, saṅkhāro āsavapañcamo. yāva pañca pare katamā, panāvuso padānaṃ kiṃ§katamanti chabbidhā vuttaṃ, katamāni catubbidhāni. katamo pañcavidho vutto, sabbesaṃ ekasaṅkhānaṃ pañcanayapadāni cāti ]

17644.meaning_1: one reckoning; one definition; one classification
17644.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 9 phrase sabbesaṃ ekasaṅkhānaṃ pañcanayapadāni, ekasaṅkhā (gen pl ekasaṅkhānaṃ) means “of all with one and the same reckoning/definition”, i.e. sharing a single classification.
17644.example_1: yāva pañca pare katamā, panāvuso padānaṃ kiṃ§katamanti chabbidhā vuttaṃ, katamāni catubbidhāni. katamo pañcavidho vutto, sabbesaṃ ekasaṅkhānaṃ pañcanayapadāni cāti ]

39813.meaning_1: (gram) fivefold expression; set of five technical terms
39813.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Compound of pañca ‘five’ + naya ‘method, way of analysis’ + pada ‘term/word’. In the MN9 citation the phrase sabbesaṃ ekasaṅkhānaṃ pañcanayapadāni refers to ‘the fivefold set of terms’ used for a single reckoning, i.e. five ways of expressing/analysing the same item.
39813.example_1: yāva pañca pare katamā, panāvuso padānaṃ kiṃ§katamanti chabbidhā vuttaṃ, katamāni catubbidhāni. katamo pañcavidho vutto, sabbesaṃ ekasaṅkhānaṃ pañcanayapadāni cāti ]

51931.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “MN10 mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttaṃ, maggasaccaniddeso … niṭṭhitaṃ dasamaṃ,” the form mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttaṃ is accusative singular of the title. The headword “2” distinguishes it from satipaṭṭhānasutta (MN10). DN22 is the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna.

26916.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In mn10:31.6 “cuddasakāyānupassanā niṭṭhitā” means “the fourteen contemplations of the body are completed.” The compound is a digu specifying the number of items in kāyānupassanā.

64283.meaning_1: commentary on the Dīgha Nikāya compiled by Buddhaghosa
64283.meaning_lit: She who delights in auspiciousness; Auspiciously charming
64283.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
A proper name of the Dīghanikāya commentary. In the contextual sentence the bracketed phrase indicates consulting the Sumaṅgalavilāsinī for explanation. The compound is an adjectival-kammadhāraya: vilāsinī (graceful/charming woman) that is sumaṅgala (very auspicious).
64283.example_1: katamañca, bhikkhave, maraṇaṃ? yaṃ [sumaṅgalavilāsinī oloketabbā] tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhā tamhā sattanikāyā cuti cavanatā bhedo antaradhānaṃ maccu maraṇaṃ kālaṅkiriyā khandhānaṃ bhedo kaḷevarassa nikkhepo jīvitindriyassupacchedo, idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, maraṇaṃ.

8480.meaning_1: attainment of the deathless; realizing the deathless state
8480.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the MN10 uddāna line “ajaraṃ amataṃ amatādhigamaṃ …”, the compound means “the attainment of the deathless (Nibbāna).” The long ā arises through sandhi of final a of amata and initial a of adhigama.
8480.example_1: tassuddānaṃ, [ito paraṃ kesuci potthakesu imāpi gāthāyo evaṃ dissanti –§ajaraṃ amataṃ amatādhigamaṃ, phalamagganidassanaṃ dukkhanudaṃ. sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ, bhūtamiti sāraṃ vividhaṃ suṇātha.§taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe, tividhaggipiḷesitanibbāpanaṃ.

47614.meaning_1: manifestation of the fruit and the path; showing the path and its fruition
47614.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the MN10 uddāna verse phalamagganidassanaṃ functions as a neuter noun in -aṃ, meaning “showing/manifestation of the (Noble) Path and its Fruition,” summarizing themes of magga and phala.
47614.example_1: tassuddānaṃ, [ito paraṃ kesuci potthakesu imāpi gāthāyo evaṃ dissanti –§ajaraṃ amataṃ amatādhigamaṃ, phalamagganidassanaṃ dukkhanudaṃ. sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ, bhūtamiti sāraṃ vividhaṃ suṇātha.§taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe, tividhaggipiḷesitanibbāpanaṃ.

61486.meaning_1: fact of being united; state of being consistent
61486.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the MN10 uddāna line “sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ ...” it functions as an abstract neuter meaning “the state of being well-united/consistent,” likely praising the coherence or harmony (of Dhamma teachings or benefits).
61486.example_1: tassuddānaṃ, [ito paraṃ kesuci potthakesu imāpi gāthāyo evaṃ dissanti –§ajaraṃ amataṃ amatādhigamaṃ, phalamagganidassanaṃ dukkhanudaṃ. sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ, bhūtamiti sāraṃ vividhaṃ suṇātha.§taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe, tividhaggipiḷesitanibbāpanaṃ. byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ.

51906.meaning_1: maker of the great thousandfold (wheel); producing a great thousand; bringing about a great thousand
51906.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Occurs in a gāthā of the uddāna for MN 10: sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ. Here it functions as a bahubbīhi-like epithet agreeing with sahitattaṃ, “having a collected mind that brings about a great thousand,” i.e. producing the great thousandfold effect or benefit. The internal member rasa is obscure/poetic; the overall sense is “making/bringing about a great thousand.”
51906.example_1: tassuddānaṃ, [ito paraṃ kesuci potthakesu imāpi gāthāyo evaṃ dissanti –§ajaraṃ amataṃ amatādhigamaṃ, phalamagganidassanaṃ dukkhanudaṃ. sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ, bhūtamiti sāraṃ vividhaṃ suṇātha.§taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe, tividhaggipiḷesitanibbāpanaṃ. byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ.

66519.meaning_1: filled with wealth; filled with goodness
66519.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the verse “taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe…”, vasupūritaṃ agrees with taḷākaṃ (nt acc sg), describing a pond “filled with wealth”, i.e. richly supplied (with water or resources). Here vasu is used in the sense of abundance or richness.
66519.example_1: tassuddānaṃ, [ito paraṃ kesuci potthakesu imāpi gāthāyo evaṃ dissanti –§ajaraṃ amataṃ amatādhigamaṃ, phalamagganidassanaṃ dukkhanudaṃ. sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ, bhūtamiti sāraṃ vividhaṃ suṇātha.§taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe, tividhaggipiḷesitanibbāpanaṃ. byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ.

25525.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the verse taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe, the sense is a reservoir filled with water on a heat-scorched road, highlighting relief from heat for travelers.
25525.example_1: tassuddānaṃ, [ito paraṃ kesuci potthakesu imāpi gāthāyo evaṃ dissanti –§ajaraṃ amataṃ amatādhigamaṃ, phalamagganidassanaṃ dukkhanudaṃ. sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ, bhūtamiti sāraṃ vividhaṃ suṇātha.§taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe, tividhaggipiḷesitanibbāpanaṃ. byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ.

30881.meaning_1: extinguishing the three fires that afflict one
30881.meaning_lit: extinguishing of the affliction by the three fires
30881.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the MN10 uddāna line “tividhaggipiḷesitanibbāpanaṃ,” the compound denotes the calming/extinguishing of the threefold fires (lobha, dosa, moha) that oppress beings; here it functions as a neuter nominative singular item in a list of summaries.
30881.example_1: tassuddānaṃ, [ito paraṃ kesuci potthakesu imāpi gāthāyo evaṃ dissanti –§ajaraṃ amataṃ amatādhigamaṃ, phalamagganidassanaṃ dukkhanudaṃ. sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ, bhūtamiti sāraṃ vividhaṃ suṇātha.§taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe, tividhaggipiḷesitanibbāpanaṃ. byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ.

39665.meaning_lit: the last sutta which is excellent
39665.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the verse, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā is nom pl (ā) agreeing with osadhayo (fem pl), referring to “the excellent final discourses” that are established/laid down as remedies. Here the headword is the compound in its neuter stem form meaning “final excellent discourse”.
39665.example_1: sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ, bhūtamiti sāraṃ vividhaṃ suṇātha.§taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe, tividhaggipiḷesitanibbāpanaṃ. byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ. tathā sutte veyyākaraṇā ṭhapitā, sakyaputtānamabhidamanatthāya.§paññāsaṃ ca diyaḍḍhasataṃ, dve ca veyyākaraṇaṃ apare ca.

29001.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the cited MN10 context “tathā sutte veyyākaraṇā ṭhapitā” means “explanations are set out/presented (there) in the sutta,” hence the sense “set out; presented; stated.”
29001.example_1: byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ. tathā sutte veyyākaraṇā ṭhapitā, sakyaputtānamabhidamanatthāya.§paññāsaṃ ca diyaḍḍhasataṃ, dve ca veyyākaraṇaṃ apare ca. tevanāmagataṃ ca anupubbaṃ, ekamanā nisāmetha mudaggaṃ.]

5186.meaning_1: a moment; an instant; a finger-snap
5186.phonetic: ṃgh > ṅgh; a > ā before ghāt
5186.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Form anusaṅghātaṃ is acc sg of neuter anusaṅghāta. In the verse khiḍḍārati jananim anusaṅghātaṃ, it denotes a very short time “in an instant; in a finger-snap,” describing how quickly delight arises.
5186.example_1: sahitattaṃ mahārasahassakaraṃ, bhūtamiti sāraṃ vividhaṃ suṇātha.§taḷākaṃ vasupūritaṃ ghammapathe, tividhaggipiḷesitanibbāpanaṃ. byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ. tathā sutte veyyākaraṇā ṭhapitā, sakyaputtānamabhidamanatthāya.§paññāsaṃ ca diyaḍḍhasataṃ, dve ca veyyākaraṇaṃ apare ca.

7750.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Abstract action noun in -ana from abhidameti “to tame thoroughly”. In the cited verse “sakyaputtānaṃ abhidamanatthāya” it appears in the -attha dative compound sense “for the purpose of complete taming (training)” of the Sakyans; base meaning is “thorough taming; complete self-mastery”.
7750.example_1: byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ. tathā sutte veyyākaraṇā ṭhapitā, sakyaputtānamabhidamanatthāya.§paññāsaṃ ca diyaḍḍhasataṃ, dve ca veyyākaraṇaṃ apare ca. tevanāmagataṃ ca anupubbaṃ, ekamanā nisāmetha mudaggaṃ.]

40084.meaning_1: set of fifty; group of fifty (suttas)
40084.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the verse, paññāsaṃ ca diyaḍḍhasataṃ counts texts: paññāsa (50) plus diyaḍḍhasata (150) etc.; here paññāsa functions as a count of “fifty,” specifically a group/set of fifty suttas.
40084.example_1: byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ. tathā sutte veyyākaraṇā ṭhapitā, sakyaputtānamabhidamanatthāya.§paññāsaṃ ca diyaḍḍhasataṃ, dve ca veyyākaraṇaṃ apare ca. tevanāmagataṃ ca anupubbaṃ, ekamanā nisāmetha mudaggaṃ.]

32633.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the MN10 verse, paññāsaṃ ca diyaḍḍhasataṃ means “fifty and one hundred fifty,” enumerating counts; diyaḍḍhasataṃ is neuter accusative singular of the cardinal compound.
32633.example_1: byādhipanudanaosadhayo, pacchimasuttapavarā ṭhapitā.§madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ, khiḍḍārati jananimanusaṅghātaṃ. tathā sutte veyyākaraṇā ṭhapitā, sakyaputtānamabhidamanatthāya.§paññāsaṃ ca diyaḍḍhasataṃ, dve ca veyyākaraṇaṃ apare ca. tevanāmagataṃ ca anupubbaṃ, ekamanā nisāmetha mudaggaṃ.]

52947.meaning_1: highest joy; supreme delight; peak happiness
52947.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the verse “ekamanā nisāmetha mudaggaṃ,” mudaggaṃ is neuter accusative singular of a kammadhāraya compound meaning the highest joy or supreme delight; the audience is urged to listen single-mindedly to the supreme joy (i.e. the highest teaching leading to Nibbāna).
52947.example_1: tathā sutte veyyākaraṇā ṭhapitā, sakyaputtānamabhidamanatthāya.§paññāsaṃ ca diyaḍḍhasataṃ, dve ca veyyākaraṇaṃ apare ca. tevanāmagataṃ ca anupubbaṃ, ekamanā nisāmetha mudaggaṃ.]

63328.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context mn20:8.17, sīhanādavaggo niṭṭhito dutiyo means 'the Sīhanāda chapter is finished, the second (chapter)'; thus the headword denotes the second vagga of the Majjhima Nikāya, conventionally covering MN11–20.

26994.meaning_2: The Shorter Discourse on the Lion's Roar; the Shorter Lion’s Roar
26994.meaning_lit: shorter discourse on the lion's roar
26994.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
A neuter compound title of MN 11. In the sentence “cūḷasīhanādasutta — The Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar,” it functions as the sutta name; lit. ‘shorter lion’s-roar discourse’ (cūḷa ‘short, lesser’ + sīhanāda ‘lion’s roar’ + sutta ‘discourse’).
26994.example_1: The Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

57171.meaning_1: direct knowledge of the truth; realization of the truth
57171.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Form is fem in -ā, meaning 'direct knowledge of the truth'. In MN 11 gloss '[…] sakāya paṭiññāya saccābhiññehīti attho veditabbo' indicates 'by their own declaration, by the realization of the truth', i.e. saccābhiññā as the attainment/realization confirming the truth.
57171.example_1: idheva, bhikkhave, samaṇo, idha dutiyo samaṇo, idha tatiyo samaṇo, idha catuttho samaṇo, suññā parappavādā samaṇebhi aññehīti [samaṇehi aññeti ettha aññehīti sakāya paṭiññāya saccābhiññehīti attho veditabbo] . evametaṃ [evameva], bhikkhave, sammā sīhanādaṃ nadatha.

51977.meaning_lit: longer discourse on the lion's roar
51977.meaning_2: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar
51977.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In mn12:0.2, mahāsīhanādasutta functions as the title of MN 12, translated as “The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar”. The numeral 2 distinguishes this Majjhima discourse from the Dīgha Nikāya Mahāsīhanādasutta (DN 8).
51977.example_1: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

71449.meaning_1: by reason; by way of cause; as a cause; in terms of causes
71449.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In mn12:11.1, ṭhānaso hetuso means “in terms of grounds and causes”. Here hetuso functions as an adverbial ablative “by/according to cause(s)”.
71449.sutta_1: puna caparaṃ, sāriputta, tathāgato atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
71449.example_1: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of grounds and causes.

45344.meaning_1: passage in the text; place in the text; textual location
45344.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the MN12 note, imassānantare aññopi koci pāṭhapadeso … dissati means “after this, another textual passage is seen in other Ājīvakavata-dīpaka suttas,” so pāṭhapadeso refers to a specific spot or locus in the wording of the text.
45344.example_1: so sāṇānipi dhāremi, masāṇānipi dhāremi, chavadussānipi dhāremi, paṃsukūlānipi dhāremi, tirīṭānipi dhāremi, ajinampi dhāremi, ajinakkhipampi dhāremi, kusacīrampi dhāremi, vākacīrampi dhāremi, phalakacīrampi dhāremi, kesakambalampi dhāremi, vāḷakambalampi dhāremi, ulūkapakkhampi dhāremi, kesamassulocakopi homi kesamassulocanānuyogamanuyutto, ubbhaṭṭhakopi homi āsanapaṭikkhitto, ukkuṭikopi homi ukkuṭikappadhānamanuyutto, kaṇṭakāpassayikopi homi kaṇṭakāpassaye seyyaṃ kappemi [imassānantare aññopi koci pāṭhapadeso aññesu ājīvakavatadīpakasuttesu dissati], sāyatatiyakampi udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharāmi, iti evarūpaṃ anekavihitaṃ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharāmi. idaṃsu me, sāriputta, tapassitāya hoti.

11394.meaning_1: discourse which illustrates the practices of Ājīvakas
11394.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Title of a sutta cited parenthetically in MN12 as parallel passages listing ascetic practices; the compound means a discourse that sheds light (dīpaka) on the Ājīvakas’ observances (vata).
11394.example_1: so sāṇānipi dhāremi, masāṇānipi dhāremi, chavadussānipi dhāremi, paṃsukūlānipi dhāremi, tirīṭānipi dhāremi, ajinampi dhāremi, ajinakkhipampi dhāremi, kusacīrampi dhāremi, vākacīrampi dhāremi, phalakacīrampi dhāremi, kesakambalampi dhāremi, vāḷakambalampi dhāremi, ulūkapakkhampi dhāremi, kesamassulocakopi homi kesamassulocanānuyogamanuyutto, ubbhaṭṭhakopi homi āsanapaṭikkhitto, ukkuṭikopi homi ukkuṭikappadhānamanuyutto, kaṇṭakāpassayikopi homi kaṇṭakāpassaye seyyaṃ kappemi [imassānantare aññopi koci pāṭhapadeso aññesu ājīvakavatadīpakasuttesu dissati], sāyatatiyakampi udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharāmi, iti evarūpaṃ anekavihitaṃ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharāmi. idaṃsu me, sāriputta, tapassitāya hoti.

26323.meaning_lit: explanation of the meaning to the Cariyāpiṭaka
26323.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the MN12 note, the bracketed gloss directs the reader to consult the Cariyāpiṭaka commentary (cariyāpiṭakaaṭṭhakathā) regarding the variant gāmaṇḍalā/gomaṇḍalā. As a compound it means “the commentary on the Cariyāpiṭaka,” a genitival (chaṭṭhī) tappurisa.
26323.example_1: so kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, susāne seyyaṃ kappemi chavaṭṭhikāni upadhāya. apissu maṃ, sāriputta, gāmaṇḍalā [gomaṇḍalā (bahūsu) cariyāpiṭakaaṭṭhakathā oloketabbā] upasaṅkamitvā oṭṭhubhantipi, omuttentipi, paṃsukenapi okiranti, kaṇṇasotesupi salākaṃ pavesenti. na kho panāhaṃ, sāriputta, abhijānāmi tesu pāpakaṃ cittaṃ uppādetā.

30591.meaning_2: unripe-picked bitter gourd; bitter bottle-gourd cut while unripe
30591.compound_construction: titta alābu (kammadhāraya) + āmaka chinna (tappurisa: āmaka + chinna)
30591.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Occurs in MN 12 as a simile: “seyyathāpi nāma tittakālābuāmakacchinno vātātapena saṃphuṭito hoti sammilāto …” meaning “just as a bitter gourd, cut while unripe, cracks and shrivels in the wind and sun.” The compound analyses as titta ‘bitter’ + alābu ‘gourd’ (kammadhāraya) plus āmaka ‘unripe’ + chinna ‘cut, plucked’ (tappurisa), overall describing an unripe-plucked bitter gourd. The form in context is masc. nom. sg. -o.
30591.example_1: seyyathāpi nāma gambhīre udapāne udakatārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti, evamevassu me akkhikūpesu akkhitārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti tāyevappāhāratāya. seyyathāpi nāma tittakālābuāmakacchinno vātātapena saṃphuṭito [samphusito, saṃpuṭito ettha saṃphuṭitoti saṅkucitoti attho] hoti sammilāto, evamevassu me sīsacchavi saṃphuṭitā hoti sammilātā tāyevappāhāratāya. so kho ahaṃ, sāriputta, udaracchaviṃ parimasissāmīti piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃyeva pariggaṇhāmi, piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ parimasissāmīti udaracchaviṃyeva pariggaṇhāmi, yāvassu me, sāriputta, udaracchavi piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ allīnā hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.

4094.meaning_1: not lived in before; not previously inhabited
4094.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 12 the Buddha says “yo mayā anāvutthapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā,” i.e. “a dwelling which I have not inhabited before for this long time.” The compound is an- (negative) + āvuttha (pp. of vas) + pubba “before.”
4094.example_1: santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino, āvāsena suddhīti. na kho pana so, sāriputta, āvāso sulabharūpo yo mayā anāvuṭṭhapubbo [anāvutthapubbo] iminā dīghena addhunā, aññatra suddhāvāsehi devehi. suddhāvāse cāhaṃ, sāriputta, deve āvaseyyaṃ, nayimaṃ lokaṃ punarāgaccheyyaṃ.

55680.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In mn12:62.7, lahukena asanena means “with a light arrow,” showing the base sense “light (in weight),” which underlies the extended sense “quick; swift.”
55680.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, sāriputta, daḷhadhammā dhanuggaho sikkhito katahattho katūpāsano lahukena asanena appakasireneva tiriyaṃ tālacchāyaṃ atipāteyya,
55680.example_1: Imagine how easily a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow would shoot a light arrow across the shadow of a palm tree.

51734.meaning_lit: longer discourse on the mass of suffering
51734.meaning_2: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
51734.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In context mn13:0.2, the headword is the title of MN13, translated as “The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering.” The compound is mahā (great/longer) + dukkhakkhandha (mass of suffering) + sutta (discourse).
51734.example_1: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

60525.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 13, the phrase ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīṃsapasamphassehi … samphassamāno means “being tormented/affected by the stings, winds, heat, and crawling things,” i.e. being physically touched/struck by them; hence passive sense with instrumental.
60525.example_1: ko ca, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo? idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto yena sippaṭṭhānena jīvikaṃ kappeti, yadi muddāya yadi gaṇanāya yadi saṅkhānena [saṅkhāya] yadi kasiyā yadi vaṇijjāya yadi gorakkhena yadi issatthena yadi rājaporisena yadi sippaññatarena, sītassa purakkhato uṇhassa purakkhato ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīṃsapasamphassehi rissamāno [īrayamāno, samphassamāno (cūḷani. khaggavisāṇasutta 136)] khuppipāsāya mīyamāno, ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu.

18806.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
omaddati is a causative-like active present from ava + √madd “to crush down”. In MN 13, abhivaggena omaddanti means “they crush (them) by a superior force”, i.e. overpower or trample down, with an accusative object.
18806.sutta_1: te tattha usūhipi vijjhanti, sattiyāpi vijjhanti, chakaṇakāyapi osiñcanti, abhivaggenapi omaddanti, asināpi sīsaṃ chindanti.
18806.example_1: There they are struck with arrows and spears, splashed with dung, crushed by a superior force, and their heads are chopped off,

44507.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Bahubbīhi adjective meaning “with gray hair,” built on kammadhāraya palita + kesī. In MN 13 it appears as acc sg fem palitakesiṃ describing the elderly woman seen by the observer.
44507.example_1: ko ca, bhikkhave, rūpānaṃ ādīnavo? idha, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṃ passeyya aparena samayena āsītikaṃ vā nāvutikaṃ vā vassasatikaṃ vā jātiyā, jiṇṇaṃ gopānasivaṅkaṃ bhoggaṃ daṇḍaparāyanaṃ pavedhamānaṃ gacchantiṃ āturaṃ gatayobbanaṃ khaṇḍadantaṃ [khaṇḍadantiṃ] palitakesaṃ [palitakesiṃ], vilūnaṃ khalitasiraṃ valinaṃ tilakāhatagattaṃ [tilakāhatagattiṃ (bahūsu) aṭṭhakathā ṭīkā oloketabbā] . taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?

26965.meaning_lit: shorter discourse on the mass of suffering
26965.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the contextual sentence mn14:0.2, the headword is the sutta title “The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering”, matching MN 14.
26965.example_1: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

37067.meaning_1: to purge; to wear away; to expiate; to cause to be worn off
37067.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 14 the nigaṇṭhas say: “purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantibhāvā … sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissati,” and urge “taṃ … nijjīretha [nijjaretha]” — i.e. “you should purge/wear away it (the former evil action) with this austere practice.” Here nijjareti (impv pl nijjaretha) means “to purge; wear away; expiate (evil karma).”
37067.example_1: evaṃ vutte, mahānāma, te nigaṇṭhā maṃ etadavocuṃ, nigaṇṭho, āvuso, nāṭaputto [nāthaputto] sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paṭijānāti, carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṃ samitaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhitanti. so evamāha, atthi kho vo [atthi kho bho], nigaṇṭhā, pubbe pāpakammaṃ kataṃ, taṃ imāya kaṭukāya dukkarakārikāya nijjīretha [nijjaretha], yaṃ panettha [mayaṃ panettha] etarahi kāyena saṃvutā vācāya saṃvutā manasā saṃvutā taṃ āyatiṃ pāpassa kammassa akaraṇaṃ, iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantibhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo, āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo, kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo, dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo, vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatīti. tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca, tena camha attamanāti.

5046.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the contextual sentence, anumānasutta refers to the title MN15, translated there as “Measuring Up,” a discourse centered on reasoning by inference.

64662.meaning_1: name of the capital city of the Bhagga
64662.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 15, āyasmā Mahāmoggallāna is staying ‘susumāragire [suṃsumāragire] bhesakaḷāvane’, i.e. at Suṃsumāragira, the capital of the Bhagga. The compound means ‘the call/roar of the crocodile’ and functions as a place-name (masc a-stem).
64662.example_1: 181. evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhaggesu viharati susumāragire [suṃsumāragire] bhesakaḷāvane migadāye. tatra kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhikkhū āmantesi, āvuso, bhikkhavoti.

27115.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
The contextual sentence mn16:0.2 identifies this as MN16, titled Cetokhilasutta, often rendered “Hard-heartedness,” referring to the concept of mental barrenness (ceto-khila).

27064.meaning_1: bound by the mind; fettered by the heart
27064.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 16 the plural cetasovinibaddhā (var. cetovinibaddhā) refers to “mental bonds” that, together with the five mental obstructions (cetokhilā), prevent growth in the Dhamma. The form is an adjectival compound “bound of/by the mind,” functioning substantivally in the list.
27064.example_1: yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pañca cetokhilā appahīnā, pañca cetasovinibandhā [cetasovinibaddhā, cetovinibaddhā (sāratthadīpanīṭīkā)] asamucchinnā, so vatimasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjissatīti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

27147.meaning_1: mental bondage; mental tie; fetter of the mind
27147.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 16 the phrase pañca cetasovinibandhā/cetasovinibaddhā refers to the five “mental bondages”. The form cetovinibaddha is a ceto- compound = “of the mind” + vinibaddha “bound, fastened”, hence “mental bondage/tie”. The neuter usage matches the set of five items functioning as abstract bonds.
27147.example_1: yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pañca cetokhilā appahīnā, pañca cetasovinibandhā [cetasovinibaddhā, cetovinibaddhā (sāratthadīpanīṭīkā)] asamucchinnā, so vatimasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjissatīti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

11842.meaning_1: attains; achieves; reaches (a stage or development)
11842.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 16 “vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjissati” means “will attain/achieve growth, improvement, and maturity.” This sense is intransitive and denotes reaching a state rather than taking a direct object.
11842.sutta_1: “yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pañca cetokhilā appahīnā, pañca cetasovinibandhā asamucchinnā, so vatimasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
11842.example_1: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has not given up five kinds of hard-heartedness and severed five shackles of the heart, it’s not possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

66200.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the contextual sentence “vanapatthasutta — Jungle Thickets”, the word functions as the title of MN17. Vanapattha means woodland thickets; the compound with sutta yields “Discourse on Jungle Thickets.”

51055.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context line “madhupiṇḍikasutta — The Honey-Cake”, the headword is the sutta title (MN 18). The literal sense is “discourse on the honey-lump/ball,” often rendered “Honeyball Sutta.”

34474.meaning_2: Two Kinds of Thought; the Discourse on Two Sorts of Thinking
34474.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In context mn19:0.2 this is the title “Two Kinds of Thought,” i.e. the discourse where the Buddha classifies thinking into two groups (unwholesome vs wholesome). The lit. sense is “twofold-thought discourse.”

21828.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 19, the bracketed gloss [atītakālikakiriyāpadāniyeva] identifies the verbs pajahama, vinodama, byantama, akāsiṃ as “past-time verb forms,” showing kiriyāpada used in a grammatical, metalinguistic sense to refer to the verbal/predicate element.
21828.example_1: attabyābādhāya saṃvattatītipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṃ gacchati, parabyābādhāya saṃvattatītipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṃ gacchati, ubhayabyābādhāya saṃvattatītipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṃ gacchati, paññānirodhiko vighātapakkhiko anibbānasaṃvattanikotipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṃ gacchati. so kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, uppannuppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ pajahameva [atītakālikakiriyāpadāniyeva] vinodameva [atītakālikakiriyāpadāniyeva] byantameva [byanteva] naṃ akāsiṃ.

21844.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 19: kāye kilante [kilamante] means “when the body becomes tired,” showing prp in an intransitive sense with instr nuance “from (doing so long).”
21844.example_1: api ca kho me aticiraṃ anuvitakkayato anuvicārayato kāyo kilameyya. kāye kilante [kilamante] cittaṃ ūhaññeyya. ūhate citte ārā cittaṃ samādhimhāti.

14247.meaning_1: struck up; agitated; disturbed; opened up
14247.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 19 the reading contrasts ūhaññi vs ugghāṭi/ūhani. Here ugghāṭi is the aorist “was agitated/struck up,” describing the mind being stirred; hence aorist, transitive sense with implied object “cittaṃ.”
14247.example_1: taṃ kissa hetu? mā me cittaṃ ūhaññīti [ugghāṭīti, ūhanīti] .

58966.meaning_1: all the crops; the entire harvest; all kinds of crops
58966.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 19: seyyathāpi ... gimhānaṃ pacchime māse sabbasassesu gāmantasambhatesu, sabbasassa occurs in the locative plural sabbasassesu, meaning ‘when all the crops (have been) gathered.’ The headword is a kammadhāraya compound sabba ‘all’ + sassa ‘crop,’ denoting the entirety of the harvest.
58966.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gimhānaṃ pacchime māse sabbasassesu gāmantasambhatesu gopālako gāvo rakkheyya, tassa rukkhamūlagatassa vā abbhokāsagatassa vā satikaraṇīyameva hoti:
58966.example_1: Suppose it’s the last month of summer, when all the crops have been gathered within a village, and a cowherd must take care of the cattle. While at the root of a tree or in the open he need only be mindful that

7749.meaning_1: with the teeth set against the teeth; with teeth clenched
7749.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 20 the phrase dantebhidantamādhāya is glossed in the ṭīkā as dante + abhidantaṃ + ādhāya, meaning “placing (the tongue) with the teeth set against the teeth.” Here abhidantaṃ is an indeclinable adverbial compound (avyayībhāva) from abhi + danta, used adverbially to describe the manner (with teeth clenched) in the practice of restraining the mind.
7749.example_1: tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno tesampi vitakkānaṃ vitakkasaṅkhārasaṇṭhānaṃ manasikaroto uppajjanteva pāpakā akusalā vitakkā chandūpasaṃhitāpi dosūpasaṃhitāpi mohūpasaṃhitāpi. tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā dantebhidantamādhāya [dante + abhidantaṃ + ādhāyāti ṭīkāyaṃ padacchedo, dantebhīti panettha karaṇattho yutto viya dissati] jivhāya tāluṃ āhacca cetasā cittaṃ abhiniggaṇhitabbaṃ abhinippīḷetabbaṃ abhisantāpetabbaṃ. tassa dantebhidantamādhāya jivhāya tāluṃ āhacca cetasā cittaṃ abhiniggaṇhato abhinippīḷayato abhisantāpayato ye pāpakā akusalā vitakkā chandūpasaṃhitāpi dosūpasaṃhitāpi mohūpasaṃhitāpi te pahīyanti te abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.

18703.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the sentence “opammavaggo niṭṭhito tatiyo.” it functions as the subject “the Opamma Chapter,” i.e. the third chapter, is completed.

19167.meaning_2: The Simile of the Saw; discourse on the simile of the saw
19167.meaning_lit: discourse on the simile of the saw
19167.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Title of MN21; in context it functions as a proper neuter compound noun meaning “The Simile of the Saw”. The internal form is kakacūpamā + sutta, i.e. “saw-simile discourse”.

31129.meaning_1: downy; fleecy; soft like cotton; cottony
31129.meaning_lit: made of cotton; full of down
31129.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In context mudukaṃ tūliniṃ describes the catskin bag as soft and downy/cottony; tūlinī is an ī-stem adjective from tūla “cotton, down,” meaning “downy, soft like cotton.” Related to Skt tūlinī.
31129.sutta_1: ‘ahaṃ imaṃ biḷārabhastaṃ madditaṃ sumadditaṃ suparimadditaṃ, mudukaṃ tūliniṃ, chinnasassaraṃ chinnabhabbharaṃ kaṭṭhena vā kathalena vā sarasaraṃ karissāmi bharabharaṃ karissāmī’ti.
31129.example_1: ‘I shall make this soft catskin bag rustle and crackle with this stick or stone.’

24309.meaning_1: who was previously a perfume-seller; formerly a dealer in scents
24309.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 22, Ariṭṭha is described as gandhabādhipubba, i.e. “formerly a perfumes merchant.” The variant gaddhabādhipubba (with ddh) is a scribal corruption; context and standard compounding with pubba indicate a previous occupation. The middle member bādhi (from bādhati/bādheti in the instrumental sense of “pressing, extracting”) yields “one who presses/works with scents.”
24309.example_1: evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme. tena kho pana samayena ariṭṭhassa nāma bhikkhuno gaddhabādhipubbassa [gandhabādhipubbassa] evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ hoti, tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi yathā yeme antarāyikā dhammā vuttā bhagavatā te paṭisevato nālaṃ antarāyāyāti. assosuṃ kho sambahulā bhikkhū, ariṭṭhassa kira nāma bhikkhuno gaddhabādhipubbassa evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ, tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi yathā yeme antarāyikā dhammā vuttā bhagavatā te paṭisevato nālaṃ antarāyāyāti.

56397.meaning_1: (gram) conforming to the Sanskrit; according with the “Sanskritised” form
56397.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
sakkata is the Pāḷi reflex of Skt saṃskṛta “Sanskrit; refined speech.” As a kammadhāraya, sakkatānurūpa means “Sanskrit-conforming.” In the cited MN23 reading note, it labels a variant “in the Sanskritised form” (i.e. spelling/sandhi that follows Sanskrit).
56397.example_1: bhikkhu bhikkhu, ayaṃ vammiko [vammīko (katthaci) sakkatānurūpaṃ] rattiṃ dhūmāyati, divā pajjalati. brāhmaṇo evamāha, abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṃ ādāyāti.

43883.meaning_1: crushing and breaking; abrasion and breakage
43883.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 23 vammikasutta, it occurs in the sequence aniccucchādana-parimaddanabhedana-viddhaṃsana-dhammassa, describing the body’s nature as subject to rubbing away (abrasion/crushing) and breaking apart, i.e. processes of decay and disintegration.
43883.example_1: 251. vammikoti kho, bhikkhu, imassetaṃ cātumahābhūtikassa [cātummahābhūtikassa] kāyassa adhivacanaṃ, mātāpettikasambhavassa odanakummāsūpacayassa aniccucchādana-parimaddanabhedana-viddhaṃsana-dhammassa.

54633.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “rathavinītasutta — Chariots at the Ready”, the headword is the title of MN24, known for the simile of relay chariots; hence a neuter compound meaning “the discourse on relay chariots”.

27168.meaning_1: cloth pad; pad placed on the head for carrying heavy items
27168.meaning_2: head-pad; head-rest made of cloth for bearing loads
27168.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 24 the instrumental celaṇḍukena/celaṇḍakena refers to a cloth head-pad used for carrying heavy loads on the head while venerating a senior monk. Form varies with -ka/-kaṃ vs. -uka/-ukaṃ; both denote the same implement.
27168.example_1: lābhā sabrahmacārīnaṃ, suladdhalābhā sabrahmacārīnaṃ, ye āyasmantaṃ puṇṇaṃ mantāṇiputtaṃ labhanti dassanāya, labhanti payirūpāsanāya. celaṇḍukena [celaṇḍakena, celaṇḍupekena (?)] cepi sabrahmacārī āyasmantaṃ puṇṇaṃ mantāṇiputtaṃ muddhanā pariharantā labheyyuṃ dassanāya, labheyyuṃ payirūpāsanāya, tesampi lābhā tesampi suladdhaṃ, amhākampi lābhā amhākampi suladdhaṃ, ye mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ puṇṇaṃ mantāṇiputtaṃ labhāma dassanāya, labhāma payirūpāsanāyāti.

38412.meaning_2: Nivāpa Sutta; the discourse on bait/lure
38412.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN25, nivāpa “bait; lure” is used in a simile; the English line “Sowing” is misleading here, as the sutta concerns bait rather than sowing.

23242.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the MN26 note, rāmāyattāni kriyapadāni refers to verbs dependent on “Rāma,” explained as coming in the past tense (atītakāla). Hence kriyapada here explicitly means “verb form(s).”
23242.example_1: so kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, kiṃ kusalagavesī anuttaraṃ santivarapadaṃ pariyesamāno yena udako [uddako] rāmaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ, upasaṅkamitvā udakaṃ rāmaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ, icchāmahaṃ, āvuso [āvuso rāma mahāsatto rāmaputtameva avoca, na rāmaṃ, rāmo hi tattha gaṇācariyo bhaveyya, tadā ca kālaṅkato asanto. tenevettha rāmāyattāni kriyapadāni atītakālavasena āgatāni, udako ca rāmaputto mahāsattassa sabrahmacārītveva vutto, na ācariyoti. ṭīkāyaṃ ca pāḷiyaṃ rāmasseva samāpattilābhitā āgatā na udakassāti ādi pacchābhāge pakāsitā], imasmiṃ dhammavinaye brahmacariyaṃ caritunti.

39624.meaning_1: back part; later section; latter part
39624.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Form in context is pacchābhāge, the locative singular “in the latter part; later on.” In the cited passage “... ādi pacchābhāge pakāsitā” means “the rest is explained later (in the latter part).”
39624.example_1: tenevettha rāmāyattāni kriyapadāni atītakālavasena āgatāni, udako ca rāmaputto mahāsattassa sabrahmacārītveva vutto, na ācariyoti. ṭīkāyaṃ ca pāḷiyaṃ rāmasseva samāpattilābhitā āgatā na udakassāti ādi pacchābhāge pakāsitā], imasmiṃ dhammavinaye brahmacariyaṃ caritunti. evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, udako rāmaputto maṃ etadavoca, viharatāyasmā, tādiso ayaṃ dhammo yattha viññū puriso nacirasseva sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyāti.

62467.meaning_1: sub-commentary on the Vinaya, commenting on Buddhaghosa's Samantapāsādikā
62467.meaning_lit: sub-commentary that illuminates the essence of the meaning
62467.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
A title of a Vinaya sub-commentary (ṭīkā). In the cited MN26 variant note, the reading bāhuliko ... sāratthadīpanīṭīkāya sameti indicates that the interpretation accords with the Sāratthadīpanīṭīkā.
62467.example_1: addasaṃsu kho maṃ, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū dūrato āgacchantaṃ. disvāna aññamaññaṃ saṇṭhapesuṃ [aññamaññaṃ katikaṃ saṇṭhapesuṃ (vinayapiṭake mahāvagge)], ayaṃ kho, āvuso, samaṇo gotamo āgacchati bāhulliko [bāhuliko sāratthadīpanīṭīkāya sameti] padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya. so neva abhivādetabbo, na paccuṭṭhātabbo, nāssa pattacīvaraṃ paṭiggahetabbaṃ.

27011.meaning_lit: shorter discourse on the simile of the elephant's footprint
27011.phonetic: ā > o before p (upamā + sutta > upamasutta); au > o (sandhi in comp)
27011.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Title of MN27, rendered in the contextual sentence as “The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint”. The compound means the shorter sutta (cūḷa … sutta) concerning the elephant-footprint simile (hatthipada-upamā).
27011.example_1: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

35568.meaning_1: is not seen; is not observed; does not appear
35568.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 27 parenthetical note: “( ) etthantare pāṭho idha nadissati ... dissati ...” = “the reading is not seen here ... is seen ...”. Hence nadissati means “is not seen/attested (here)”.
35568.example_1: 296. so iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, (imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato) [( ) etthantare pāṭho idha nadissati, catukkaṅguttare pana imasmiṃ ṭhāne dissati, aṭṭhakathāṭīkāsu ca tadattho pakāsito. tasmā so ettha paṭīpūrito] iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ.

25862.meaning_1: Book 4 of the Aṅguttara Nikāya; Book of Fours
25862.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the MN27 note, “catukkaṅguttare … dissati” refers to the Aṅguttara Nikāya Book of Fours, indicating that the parenthetical reading is attested there.
25862.example_1: 296. so iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, (imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato) [( ) etthantare pāṭho idha nadissati, catukkaṅguttare pana imasmiṃ ṭhāne dissati, aṭṭhakathāṭīkāsu ca tadattho pakāsito. tasmā so ettha paṭīpūrito] iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ.

29749.meaning_1: that meaning; meaning of that; its sense; the sense intended there
29749.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 27 the aṭṭhakathāṭīkāsu ca tadattho pakāsito means “and its meaning is explained in the commentaries and subcommentaries,” where tadattho = tadevattha (the meaning of that [reading/passage]).
29749.example_1: 296. so iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, (imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato) [( ) etthantare pāṭho idha nadissati, catukkaṅguttare pana imasmiṃ ṭhāne dissati, aṭṭhakathāṭīkāsu ca tadattho pakāsito. tasmā so ettha paṭīpūrito] iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ.

41114.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Context: tasmā so ettha paṭīpūrito indicates “therefore he is complete/filled here,” i.e. the set of trainings is made complete by the item just mentioned. The form is the past participle of the causative pūreti with prefix pati-, meaning “filled up; completed.”
41114.example_1: so iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, (imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato) [( ) etthantare pāṭho idha nadissati, catukkaṅguttare pana imasmiṃ ṭhāne dissati, aṭṭhakathāṭīkāsu ca tadattho pakāsito. tasmā so ettha paṭīpūrito] iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ. so pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā, ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.

52042.meaning_2: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint
52042.meaning_lit: great discourse on the simile of the elephant's footprint
52042.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Lemma in the citation functions as the title of MN28; the English line “The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint” is the standard translation of this sutta title.
52042.example_1: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

62848.meaning_2: works out; comes off; is successful
62848.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 95 the optional gloss evameva sijjhatīti explains that one who says ‘thus it succeeds/works out’ still only guards truth, without final determination. Here sijjhati means ‘it turns out (to be so); it works out/succeeds’ rather than active accomplishment.
