62848.example_1: saccānurakkhaṇaṃ mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ pucchāmāti. saddhā cepi, bhāradvāja, purisassa hoti, evaṃ me saddhāti, iti vadaṃ saccamanurakkhati [evameva sijjhatīti iti vā, taṃ saccamanurakkhati], natveva tāva ekaṃsena niṭṭhaṃ gacchati, idameva saccaṃ, moghamaññanti ( ) [(ettāvatā kho bhāradvāja saccānurakkhaṇā hoti, ettāvatā saccamanurakkhati, ettāvatā ca mayaṃ saccānurakkhaṇaṃ paññāpema, na tveva tāva saccānubodho hoti)] . ruci cepi, bhāradvāja, purisassa hoti … anussavo cepi, bhāradvāja, purisassa hoti … ākāraparivitakko cepi, bhāradvāja, purisassa hoti … diṭṭhinijjhānakkhanti cepi, bhāradvāja, purisassa hoti, evaṃ me diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantīti, iti vadaṃ saccamanurakkhati, natveva tāva ekaṃsena niṭṭhaṃ gacchati, idameva saccaṃ, moghamaññanti.

51959.meaning_lit: great discourse on the simile of the heartwood
51959.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the contextual sentence, mahāsāropamasutta is the title of MN 29, rendered in English as “The Longer Simile of the Heartwood”. The compound means the great/major discourse featuring the heartwood simile.
51959.example_1: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

5000.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In mn30:22.2, anubhavissati (fut of anubhavati) takes the object taṃ atthaṃ “that purpose/benefit,” meaning “he will achieve/succeed in that purpose,” i.e. he will succeed in producing what is needed from the heartwood.
5000.sutta_1: yañcassa sārena sārakaraṇīyaṃ tañcassa atthaṃ anubhavissati.
5000.example_1: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he will succeed.

26992.meaning_lit: shorter discourse on the simile of the heartwood
26992.sanskrit: kṣulla, kṣudra + sāra + upamā + sūkta, sūtra
26992.phonetic: ū + a > ūs; a + u > o
26992.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In context mn30:0.2, cūḷasāropamasutta is the title “The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood,” matching MN 30.
26992.example_1: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

51897.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the sentence “mahāyamakavaggo niṭṭhito catuttho.” the noun is nominative singular; catuttho qualifies mahāyamakavaggo as “the fourth [chapter] is finished.”

26962.meaning_2: the Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga; the Lesser Gosiṅga Sutta
26962.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “cūḷagosiṅgasutta — The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga,” the term is a neuter title of MN31, a kammadhāraya compound where cūḷa ‘shorter/lesser’ qualifies gosiṅga, the place-name, followed by sutta ‘discourse’.

51692.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “mahāgosiṅgasutta — The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga,” the term names MN32, a neuter compound meaning the longer (mahā) discourse set at Gosiṅga, a place-name; sutta is the head.

51691.meaning_2: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd
51691.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “mahāgopālakasutta — The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd,” the compound names MN33; mahā qualifies gopālaka, and the whole is a kammadhāraya with sutta.
51691.example_1: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

26960.meaning_2: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd
26960.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the contextual sentence “cūḷagopālakasutta — The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd,” the term is a neuter compound title of a discourse (MN34). The compound is kammadhāraya: cūḷa “shorter” + gopālaka “cowherd” qualifying sutta “discourse.”
26960.example_1: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

26991.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
A three-member kammadhāraya compound: cūḷa (shorter) + Saccaka (name) + sutta (discourse). In MN35 it titles “The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka,” matching the contextual English.

64579.meaning_2: golden in complexion; of golden hue
64579.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In mn35:22.12 suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ is acc sg masc modifying kāyaṃ “body”: “he revealed his golden body.” The headword is a kammadhāraya compound suvaṇṇa + vaṇṇa meaning “gold-coloured.”
64579.sutta_1: iti bhagavā tasmiṃ parisati suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ kāyaṃ vivari.
64579.example_1: So the Buddha revealed his golden body to the assembly.

51928.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “mahāsaccakasutta — The Longer Discourse With Saccaka,” the headword is the title of MN36, a kammadhāraya compound: mahā (great/longer) + Saccaka (name) + sutta (discourse).

61596.meaning_1: sub-commentary to the rule on schism in the monastic order
61596.meaning_lit: sub-commentary on the schism training rule
61596.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 36 the parenthetical note bāhuliko … saṃghabhedasikkhāpadaṭīkāya sameti cites this sub-commentary (ṭīkā) to support the reading bāhuliko. The headword is a kammadhāraya/tappurisa chain meaning “the ṭīkā on the saṃghabheda-sikkhāpada,” i.e. the sub-commentary on the Vinaya rule concerning schism.
61596.example_1: tena kho pana maṃ, aggivessana, samayena pañca [pañcavaggiyā (aññasuttesu)] bhikkhū paccupaṭṭhitā honti, yaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ adhigamissati, taṃ no ārocessatīti. yato kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, oḷārikaṃ āhāraṃ āhāresiṃ odanakummāsaṃ, atha me te pañca bhikkhū nibbijja pakkamiṃsu, bāhulliko [bāhuliko saṃghabhedasikkhāpadaṭīkāya sameti] samaṇo gotamo, padhānavibbhanto, āvatto bāhullāyāti.

26964.meaning_2: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving
26964.meaning_lit: shorter discourse on the destruction of craving
26964.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Title of MN37; a kammadhāraya compound meaning “shorter discourse” (cūḷa) on the “ending of craving” (taṇhā-saṅkhaya). The contextual English matches the canonical title.
26964.example_1: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

51726.meaning_lit: longer discourse on the destruction of craving
51726.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In context (mn38:0.2), mahātaṇhāsaṅkhayasutta is the title “The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving,” referring to MN 38; it is a neuter compound ending in sutta.
51726.example_1: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

14077.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
A dvandva compound of ukkoṭana (bribery) and vañcana (cheating). In MN 38 it occurs in the stock list of trades and dishonest practices from which a bhikkhu abstains: ukkoṭanavañcana-nikati-sāciyogā paṭivirato hoti “he abstains from bribery-and-cheating, counterfeiting and crooked dealing.”
14077.example_1: so bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato hoti, ekabhattiko hoti rattūparato, virato vikālabhojanā. naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭivirato hoti, mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti, uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato hoti, jātarūparajatapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, āmakamaṃsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, ajeḷakapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, kukkuṭasūkarapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, hatthigavāssavaḷavapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, khettavatthupaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato hoti, kayavikkayā paṭivirato hoti, tulākūṭakaṃsakūṭamānakūṭā paṭivirato hoti, ukkoṭanavañcana-nikati-sāciyogā paṭivirato hoti, chedana-vadhabandhanaviparāmosa-ālopa-sahasākārā paṭivirato hoti [passa ma. ni.

66164.meaning_1: killing, tying up and highway robbery
66164.compound_construction: vadha ca bandhana ca viparāmosa ca
66164.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
A dvanda compound enumerating three forms of violence/theft prohibited in the sikkhāpada list in MN 38: killing (vadha), binding/tying (bandhana), and highway robbery or plunder (viparāmosa). The lemma appears as part of the larger series “chedana-vadhabandhanaviparāmosa-ālopa-sahasākārā … paṭivirato hoti”.
66164.example_1: so bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato hoti, ekabhattiko hoti rattūparato, virato vikālabhojanā. naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭivirato hoti, mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti, uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato hoti, jātarūparajatapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, āmakamaṃsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, ajeḷakapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, kukkuṭasūkarapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, hatthigavāssavaḷavapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, khettavatthupaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti, dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato hoti, kayavikkayā paṭivirato hoti, tulākūṭakaṃsakūṭamānakūṭā paṭivirato hoti, ukkoṭanavañcana-nikati-sāciyogā paṭivirato hoti, chedana-vadhabandhanaviparāmosa-ālopa-sahasākārā paṭivirato hoti [passa ma. ni.

68200.meaning_1: having been unpacked; having been unravelled; having been separated; having been disjoined; having been analysed in detail
68200.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 43 the reading occurs in a question about whether paññā and viññāṇa can be separated and distinguished. Here vinibbhujjitvā (passive absolutive) conveys “having been analysed/separated (into distinct aspects).”
68200.example_1: yā cāvuso, paññā yañca viññāṇaṃ, ime dhammā saṃsaṭṭhā udāhu visaṃsaṭṭhā? labbhā ca panimesaṃ dhammānaṃ vinibbhujitvā [vinibbhujjitvā vinibbhujjitvā] vinibbhujitvā nānākaraṇaṃ paññāpetunti? yā cāvuso, paññā yañca viññāṇaṃ, ime dhammā saṃsaṭṭhā, no visaṃsaṭṭhā.

67808.meaning_1: treetop; canopy; crown of a tree
67808.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN45 the phrase upari viṭabhiṃ [viṭapaṃ] kareyya means “she would make a canopy on top,” i.e. forming the treetop or leafy crown; contrasts with viṭapa 1 “branch.” The Sanskrit note “vaṭa + pā?” is incorrect; standard cognate is Skt viṭapa “branch; tuft; crown.”
67808.example_1: sā taṃ sālaṃ anuparihareyya. sā taṃ sālaṃ anupariharitvā upari viṭabhiṃ [viṭapaṃ] kareyya. upari viṭabhiṃ karitvā oghanaṃ janeyya.

62991.meaning_1: good luck; fortune; prosperity; goddess of luck
62991.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context “siriṃ āgacchantiṃ … paṭippaṇāmeyya,” siri is the personified Lady Luck/Good Fortune approaching; the simile warns against rejecting arising prosperity or auspicious opportunity.
62991.sutta_1: sace kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, brahmuno vacanaṃ upātivattissasi, seyyathāpi nāma puriso siriṃ āgacchantiṃ daṇḍena paṭippaṇāmeyya, seyyathāpi vā pana, bhikkhu, puriso narakappapāte papatanto hatthehi ca pādehi ca pathaviṃ virādheyya, evaṃ sampadamidaṃ, bhikkhu, tuyhaṃ bhavissati.
62991.example_1: If you do, then you’ll end up like a person who, when approached by Lady Luck, would ward her off with a staff; or who, as they are falling over a cliff, would lose grip of the ground with their hands and feet.

53121.meaning_1: discourse on the root; fundamental method; basic scheme; (title) the Root of All Things
53121.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the cited sentence “mūlapariyāyo ceva,” the form is nominative singular masculine used as a sutta title (MN 1), hence “the Mūlapariyāya (Sutta). The compound is kammadhāraya: a pariyāya that is “root” or fundamental.

53117.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the context mn50:33.5 “mūlapaṇṇāsakaṃ samattaṃ.” means “The Root Fifty is complete/finished,” marking the end of Book 1 of the Majjhima Nikāya.

56674.meaning_1: more dirty; more tarnished; more stained; more defiled
56674.meaning_2: even dirtier; more stained; more defiled
56674.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Comparative of saṅkiliṭṭha. In MN 5 “kaṃsapāti … saṅkiliṭṭhatarā assa” it describes the cup becoming even dirtier over time.
56674.sutta_1: evañhi sā, āvuso, kaṃsapāti aparena samayena saṅkiliṭṭhatarā assa malaggahitā”ti?
56674.example_1: Over time, wouldn’t that bronze cup get even dirtier and more stained?”

9317.meaning_1: untarnished; undefiled; untainted; uncorrupted; pure; clean
9317.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 26, asaṅkiliṭṭhaṃ is sought as the “undefiled” state, i.e. nibbāna free from defilement (saṅkilesa); here used predicatively as the goal “untainted, uncorrupted”.
9317.sutta_1: idha, bhikkhave, ekacco attanā jātidhammo samāno jātidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajātaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati, attanā jarādhammo samāno jarādhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajaraṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati, attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā abyādhiṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati, attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā amataṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati, attanā sokadhammo samāno sokadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā asokaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati, attanā saṅkilesadhammo samāno saṅkilesadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā asaṅkiliṭṭhaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati.
9317.example_1: It’s when someone who is themselves liable to be reborn, understanding the drawbacks in being liable to be reborn, seeks that which is free of rebirth, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment. Themselves liable to grow old, fall sick, die, sorrow, and become corrupted, understanding the drawbacks in these things, they seek that which is free of old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and corruption, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment.

26699.meaning_1: method for producing a thought; way of arousing a mental intention
26699.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 8 “cittupapādapariyāya” denotes the framework or method for bringing about a wholesome thought. The compound is a genitive tappurisa: “pariyāya (method) of the arising of mind”.

57630.meaning_lit: discourse on the establishments of mindfulness
57630.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the sentence “satipaṭṭhānasuttaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ dasamaṃ.” the form satipaṭṭhānasuttaṃ is accusative singular neuter, referring to the title of MN10 and indicating “the Satipaṭṭhāna Discourse” as the tenth (dasamaṃ) has concluded (niṭṭhitaṃ).

18057.meaning_1: acting like this; doing such things; behaving thus
18057.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 22 “api nu so puriso evaṅkārī tasmiṃ kulle kiccakārī assā”ti?” evaṅkārī means “one who acts like this (accordingly)”, i.e. acting in the appropriate way with the raft.
18057.sutta_1: api nu so puriso evaṅkārī tasmiṃ kulle kiccakārī assā”ti?
18057.example_1: Would that person be doing what should be done with that raft?”

73566.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 22 “kathaṅkārī … kiccakārī assa?” asks “how should he act, what should he do?” regarding the proper use of the raft; here the sense is interrogative “how-acting?” indicating manner of action.
73566.sutta_1: “kathaṅkārī ca so, bhikkhave, puriso tasmiṃ kulle kiccakārī assa?
73566.example_1: “And what, mendicants, should that person do with the raft?

73565.meaning_1: who has filled the trench; who has covered the moat
73565.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 22, saṅkiṇṇaparikkho is part of a siege metaphor for the arahant: the “moat” (parikkhā) of defilements around the fortress of the mind has been filled in and neutralized. Formally a bahubbīhi built on a dvitiya-tappurisa base “(one) having the moat filled”.
73565.sutta_1: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ukkhittapaligho itipi, saṅkiṇṇaparikkho itipi, abbūḷhesiko itipi, niraggaḷo itipi, ariyo pannaddhajo pannabhāro visaṃyutto itipi.
73565.example_1: Such a mendicant is one who is called ‘one who has lifted the cross-bar’, ‘one who has filled in the moat’, ‘one who has pulled up the pillar’, ‘one who is unimpeded’, and also ‘a noble one with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached’.

56658.meaning_1: family name of an ascetic; Kisa Saṅkicca
56658.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 36, Kiso Saṅkicco is listed among well-known ascetics; here Saṅkicca functions as a proper patronymic surname.
56658.sutta_1: nando vaccho, kiso saṅkicco, makkhali gosālo—
56658.example_1: Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkicca, and the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla.

66448.meaning_1: under control; subject to; in one’s power; subjugated
66448.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
vasaṅgato in the sentence means “under my sway/within my control.” It is a compound of vasa “control, influence” and gata “gone,” literally “gone into control,” used adjectivally to denote subjugation or being subject to someone.
66448.sutta_1: “esopi me assa hatthagato, esopi me assa vasaṅgato”ti.
66448.example_1: “Maybe this one, too, has fallen into my hands; maybe he’s under my sway!”

16211.meaning_1: dries up; withers; shrivels; wastes away
16211.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Form upassussati is a phonetic variant of upasussati. In MN 70 'sarīre upassussatu maṃsalohitaṃ' it means 'let the flesh and blood in my body dry up/waste away', expressing resolute austerity.
16211.sutta_1: ‘kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu, sarīre upassussatu maṃsalohitaṃ, yaṃ taṃ purisathāmena purisavīriyena purisaparakkamena pattabbaṃ na taṃ apāpuṇitvā vīriyassa saṇṭhānaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
16211.example_1: ‘Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not relax my energy until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’

65283.meaning_1: uterine; born of the same mother; full (brother/sister)
65283.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In context “bhātaro sodariyā” means “brothers of the same womb,” i.e. full brothers (same mother). The adjective sodariya qualifies bhātaro.
65283.sutta_1: idhāssu dve māṇavakā bhātaro sodariyā, eko ajjhāyako upanīto eko anajjhāyako anupanīto.
65283.example_1: Suppose there were two young students who were brothers who had shared a womb. One was an educated reciter, while the other was not an educated reciter.

24076.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In the contextual sentence, yathā gaṇakamoggallānasuttante refers to MN 107 as an exemplar, ‘as in the Gaṇakamoggallāna Suttanta, so it should be told in full.’ The headword is a masculine sūtrānta-compound used here in locative singular (suttante).
24076.example_1: (Tell in full as in MN 107, the Discourse with Moggallāna the Accountant.)

56675.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
In MN 127 the question contrasts saṅkiliṭṭhābhā with parisuddhābhā, i.e. deities whose radiance is defiled versus those with pure radiance; here it functions as a descriptive compound meaning “corrupted/defiled radiance.”
56675.sutta_1: yāvatā, bhante, devatā ābhā sabbā tā saṅkiliṭṭhābhā udāhu santettha ekaccā devatā parisuddhābhā”ti?
56675.example_1: Do all the radiant deities have corrupted radiance, or do some there have pure radiance?”

15200.meaning_1: upside down; with feet in the air
15200.compound_construction: uddhaṃ + pāda (acc sg in usage: pādaṃ)
15200.comment:
openrouter: openrouter/horizon-beta
Form in context is uddhampādaṃ functioning adverbially “upside down.” The lemma is given without the acc -ṃ as required. In MN 129 the phrase uddhampādaṃ adhosiraṃ “feet up, head down” describes how the guardians suspend the victims.
15200.sutta_1: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā uddhampādaṃ adhosiraṃ gahetvā vāsīhi tacchanti.
15200.example_1: They hang them upside-down and hack them with hatchets. …
